item.name: March 18
item.info:
Welcome back! I hope everyone had a restful spring break! Yesterday, the BICEP2 experiment announced the discovery of gravitational waves in the cosmic microwave background that prove inflation in the early universe - an exciting discovery for modern cosmology (more detailed description here)! We continue to gain better understanding of how our magnificent universe works, but that quest is never over! So get involved in a lab, find out something no one knows, and present it to SPS! (Yes, that is the segue I'm using - no one reads this anyway) Check out the "Physics Idol" section for more info on how to do that.

~Evan Ott, SPS President

item.name: Prospective Students Days
item.info: It moved again! Prospective Students Days is now April 3-4 (Thursday-Friday). We need volunteers throughout the event (sign up here). If you can help provide housing, please sign up here. If you signed up to help with housing, but can no longer do so, please let us know immediately.

item.name: Machine Shop, Electronics
item.info: Contact the officers if you're interested. Both have already started but if you would like to join in on the learning it may not be too late. Please contact us and we will see if you can be accomodated.

item.name: Undergraduate Lecture Series: John Loftin
item.info: TODAY, John Loftin will present a talk on "A Primer on Quantum Field Theory: the how and why of using field theory to do quantum mechanics in a relativistic setting." To get the most out of the talk, audience members should have taken Quantum 1, Electrodynamics, and Classical Dynamics.

item.name: Cheap Lunch
item.info: Come grab a cheap lunch from SPS on Wednesdays! We have pizza, chips, and a drink all for just $3!

item.name: Sunday Night Study Session
item.info: It's back! Our Sunday Night Study Session (SNSS) is in full swing! For those who haven't been, every week we invite any and all physics majors and people in physics or math classes to come by to work on homework. With many upper-division students in attendance (and some LAs for classes), when you run into problems, you won't be stuck for long. We also provide cookies, coffee, tea, etc., to help keep you <s>caffeinated</s> energized. Some come by to help or be helped! If you're interested in tutoring, making known that you're available during the night (name on a chalkboard) is a great way to earn service hours for Sigma Pi Sigma.

item.name: Physics Idol (Undergrad Research Competition)
item.info: Don't forget to reserve your slot in the new Undergraduate Research Presentation Competition during meetings this semester! Winners will be judged by a combination of a panel and popular vote, on factors covering aspects of both the research itself and its presentation. Prizes will include a custom t-shirt and a selection of prizes, not to mention bragging rights and a nice bullet-point on the resume! Sign up here.

item.name: Undergraduate Women in Physics
item.info: UT Undergraduate Women in Physics is founded on the principle of promoting equality in the sciences, especially physics, both at UT and in the general community. We welcome all people interested in furthering that goal! Join their UTList or Facebook group.
